reviewText: This is not a review of "The D.I.," because everybody already knows it's a classic and a must-see for everyone, military or not. Instead, this is a plea to the movie studio who owns the rights to "The D.I."I know some studio, or somebody, has the rights to this movie. I can get a bootleg version, probably copied from Turner Classic Movies or AMC, but I want an official, digitally remastered version of this timeless classic. Why won't the studios wake up??? They could easily sell a million copies of this movie the minute it's released. It's a no-brainer.Does anyone know who owns the rights to this film? Is there a write-in campaign somewhere that allows us to voice to the studio that we want this great film on DVD???Have the rest of you noticed that the bulk of recent DVD releases are television shows and reissued movies that have previously been released? What is going on? There are so many wonderful older movies from the forties, fifties, sixties and seventies that NEED to be released on DVD, and the studios give us TV shows.Where's "Rolling Thunder?" "Tell Them Willie Boy Is Here?" "Abandon Ship?" "Death Of A Gunfighter?" "Heroes of Telemark?" "Night of The Juggler?"Movie studios, are you listening?
summary: The Time Has Come For A DVD Release!!!

I bought it on Vhs since it was cheaper and it still holds up well. One extra note is that most of the actors who play their part are actually "Jar Heads" which add to the flavor of the video. Buy it. I think it is a nice piece of nostalgia that is not overly expensive.

reviewText: The definitive depiction of the Marine D.I. was embodied by R. Lee Ermey in Stanley Kubrick's "Full Metal Jacket".  That said, "The D.I" runs a close second.  Star-director Jack Webb working within the restrictions of the day demonstrates what it takes to meld a disparate group into a lean mean fighting unit.  Not to say there are not moments of levity here.  The funeral for the sand flea is an indiscribably classic screen moment.  As for Webb, anybody who would typecast him as a just-the-facts ma'am actor will be genuinely surprised at his multi-layered tough-but-tender technical sergeant.  The film may be a mite watered down but it is timeless in it's entertainment value.

reviewText: My father, a Vietnam-era Marine vet persuaded me to rent this movie (I would like to join up someday myself). I rented it, and I was expecting FULL METAL JACKET without cussing.Well, there isn't one "damn"  or any other swear word in this movie, simply because of the era it was  made in.The movie bored me a little, but many things were interesting,  like Webb's cruel sense of humor, and the struggle between himself and  stubborn recruit Owens. I REALLY could have done without the useless  semi-romance between Webb and some "dame" he meets in a  lounge.All in all, an _OKAY_ movie, it has its moments. An older Marine  audience will appreciate this more, but for a younger audience, this is out  of date.Give it a try.P.S. I actually visited where this film was  made on more than one occasion, San Diego MCRD.
summary: Alright, but somewhat weak by today's standards

reviewText: Others ponder why the delay of release in this great depiction of Marine boot camp, pre-Stanley Kubrick. Perhaps, because this great film depicts what is missing from our schools: regimentation, ranking by performance, standards of excellence,rote memorization (repetition), belittling individuals (for purpose), then you have the precise standards of dress, personal cleanliness,discipline and lastly respect for one's country, then the corps. Espirit de corps it's called, which creates self-respect and confidence, instead of padded advance-placement "grades." Of course, one could accuse Jack Webb of a lack of diversity compared to today. But this is the movie that captured the typical marine or navy personnel in the 50's and 60's that I experienced and witnessed. This black-and-white, taut, bluntly realistic peek of that marine corps is the standard I measure all subsequent war movies against. Few in the last 20 years measure up. Jack Webb's production stands alongside "Porkchop Hill." In fact, to create an equivalent to "Full Metal Jacket," one only needs to watch "The D.I." followed by "Pork Chop Hill." In my view, together they make a more complete "Jacket." The public martinet with private doubts that Jack Webb embodies in his D.I. , stern without being profane, rings true as a classic because of Webb's insistence on touches of weakness. (In the early 70's this film was redone in color as "Tribes," starring Darren McGavin in Webb's part and Jan Michael Vincent as the misunderstood "hippie" recruit with inner strengths. Knowing how the "entitled" "wireless" generation may prefer their realism in color, I bet the studios prefer that one; but the psychedelic camera touches make that one dated)This is the real deal, which ties the corps to tradition and high standards of conduct with a subplot like "the little engine that could" with a little encouragement, while it avoids falling into the anti-war camp making no bones about being between wars. But it is a real motivator if you want to be a part of the few, the proud and the prepared. Whether it was the start of the day or the end of the day, a marine's uniform was crisply pressed with gleaming boots. No slovenly Jack Nicholson's on display here. Better believe it!

reviewText: I first saw this back in the 60's on TV and though only once, it left a lasting impression.  Jack Webb was already a favorite from the Dragnet series, (he makes me think of the Duke as a cop) but this gave him lots of room to expand his character.  It may surprise you.  I can't help but wonder how much time Jack spent with Marine Drill Instructors to craft his role.  Also most of the men in the unit were played by Marines.  Delighted that it is now available on DVD.

reviewText: This is a very good movie that shows what it must to have been like to be a Recruit in the US Marine Corp in the late 1950's. I was in the Australian Army in the early 1980's and alot of the ways of training recuits are similiar; e.g. stand to attention when you address me, don't you eyeball me, Yes Sergeant, No Sergeant etc, but we were always told that the Australian Army didn't want robots and we could talk to our instructors, where in this movie the Marine Recruits can seem to only answer - Yes Sergeant, No Sergeant. The scene in this movie where they search for the "Sand Flea", is a good example of how petty the military can be.
summary: I am a Lean Green Fighting Machine

reviewText: Brings back the days of going through USMCRD h*ll, which was also some of the best days of my life now that I look back.  It's an absolute crime that this hasn't been officially released on DVD, along with R. Lee Ermey's "Boys of Company C."  Why these films have been resigned to sitting in dusty VHS out-of-print shelves, while other cra*py films have already been released two or three times on DVD in various special, super-special, or ultra-super-special editions is beyond me.As for the film itself, if you know the drill at all, get this movie. You'll love it.  It will bring back a flood of memories, most you'll cherish, most will motivate, and most will resonate with you long after the movie is over.  Jack Webb does an amazing performance...nails the SDI perfectly.  Can't recommend highly enough.Semper Fi brothers.

reviewText: Jack Webb was the original wooden indian as an actor but this part was tailor made for him and may just be his best film.  He is a Marine DI who is stuck with that one recruit who is just messing up the whole squad and Jack has to get him squared away.  They do what so many films of the era did by trying to introduce a love story which just detracts from the real film but not enough to keep you from enjoying what is going on with Marines.  Thanks to the miracles of modern electronics we can fast forward through all the fluff and stick with the real story.

Of course, most of the movie is spent showing Webb (as Sgt Moore) lecturing and disciplining a hapless,Gomer-type recruit named "Private Owens."  Its not flawless, but its a good Friday video (no pun intended).

reviewText: This film is a sort of time capsule of marine boot camp in the 1950s. Its best in its incredible attention to detail and its mostly real marine cast. Jack Webb gives probably the acting performance of his life as the D.I. He captured all the details of the role with incredible precision. He talks the right way. He walks the right way. He has the whole thing down cold. He was an exceptional character actor even if he had limits as a lead.The story isn't much. Its another Gomer Pyle story with some Jack Webb romance thrown in. But the story is really secondary to recreating the experience in the film. And because of when it was made and who it was made by, its a sanitized and idealized presentation. It often captures more of what the process aspired to be rather than often what it might have been.

reviewText: I saw the D I I was I was a young kid.  The movie is good entertainment by Jack Web with a clean and polish look of Marine Boot Camp.  I was drafted into the Marine Crop 1n 1969.  The Image that Jack Web show of boot camp was not true.  The physical abuse and mistreatment of Marine recruits was still there.  Because of Ribbon Creek Incident at Paris Island in 1956, no hitting of foul language was allowed toward recruits.  Officers supervision over drill instructor was greatly increase-not enough to stop the mistreatment of recruits completely. The drill instructors would use intimating tactics to prevent recruits from reporting of mistreatment by drill instructors.  A good book called Incident at Ribbon talk about the events leading up to and after the drowning of marines in ribbon creek. The book talks about what kind of training really works to produce and bond good fighting soldiers together.  I agree with the book it not the beating of recruits to make good soldiers but the leadership in the racks and bonding of small group as friends working and fighting together that produces good fighting soldiers.  No matter what ex marines tell you that it was good for them to be mistreated by drill instructors so they be good fighting soldiers, no one liked it.  From a Moral point of view it was wrong  Mike Brotsis

reviewText: Makes the Jarheads depicted in Full Metal Jacket, look like they wore lace on their panties.  This oldie has been removed from 'circulation' because it  kinda goes to a place that 'they' don't want us to go. Brainwashing.  This was actually a propoganda film to get  the gullible youth of the fifties to 'sign up'.  And because the youth of that era were of the kind they were,  it worked.  Until Vietnam.  Then chinks showed up in this type recruiting film and changes had to be made.  But excellent movie if you disregard Sgt 'Friday's poor showing as a lover.  He was a fighter though, not a lover.  Three thumbs up.  Now we know what made Sgt Friday so hard core.  He was an ex jarhead DI.  SGT MOORE GOOD DI?  SGT MOORE my DI, sir.

reviewText: When I joined the Marines in 1957, the Marine recruiter invited us recruits from Rockville, MD, to bring our gals to a screening of this movie in a theater in Washington D.C. We then left by train for Paris Island, where 13 weeks later we were first called, "Marines" at graduation. My real Drill Instructors were faithfully represented in the movie by real Marines playing most of the parts. Marine Gunny Louis Lazarko, who plays another DI and foil to Jack Web in the movie, was my boss in G-2 at 1st Marine Division HQ on Okinawa in 1959-60. He covered my back in a couple of incidents that could have hurt me. The fact that Gunny is in the movie unfairly biases me toward it. But the truth is this movie stimulates a gung-ho reminiscence of the Paris Island experience which changed my life from 17-year-old boy to young man in 3 months. Semper Fidelis to the Constitution and the Corps that defends it.
summary: I saw this movie first in 1957, just before shipping out for Paris Island as a recruit. This superb movie could not be improved.

reviewText: In terms of "definitive" representation of a Marine Drill Instructor, I have to agree with an earlier reviewer that The D. I. with Jack Webb has been replaced by the performance of R. Lee Ermey in Full Metal Jacket.  But then Ermey had been a real Marine and a real "drop and give me twenty"drill instructor.  However, that being said, it was Webb's performance that caught my attention as a boy of 12 and left a lasting impression on me that eventually led to my days as a Marine beginning in June of 1967.  I can't begin to explain the shock when I encountered my first live drill instructor at MCRD in San Diego.The D. I. takes place at MCRD Parris Island.  That doesn't really matter. Both places are equally efficient at doing what they're supposed to do.  Drill instructor Moore is a no nonsense, by-the-book, get their faces in the dirt maker of Marines.  A true believer.  But he has a "non-hacker" in his flock and he's going to get the misguided private back into civvies.  It's not until the young man's mother shows up and convinces both Sgt. Moore and the company commander that her son has what it takes.  She tells them both "you rough him up some more" and begs them not to sign the boys discharge papers.  She expects a Marine to come home.  That one scene is more a comment on the times than anything else is the movie.Of course, the realism is missing in The D. I.  No slapping, no blanket party, no language that will vaporize paint.  Still the movie holds up.For those prior service Marines out there, give this one a try.  It has a story to tell and if you're a Jack Webb fan, that's another reason to watch this one.Semper Fi and peace to all.
